conclusion: To find the potential difference between points a and b when the circular ring moves to the position shown in the figure (∠aOb = 90°).
According to Faraday's Law of Induction, the induced EMF (𝓔) in the wire is given by 𝓔 = B ⋅ l ⋅ v.
B is the magnetic field strength, l is the effective length of the wire cutting the magnetic field, v is the velocity of the wire.
The effective length l is the segment of the ring that is perpendicular to the velocity v. Since the angle ∠aOb = 90°, the effective length l is the radius R of the ring.
The total induced EMF in the circular ring is 𝓔 = B ⋅ R ⋅ v.
The potential difference between points a and b is the EMF induced across the arc from a to b. Since ∠aOb = 90°, this arc represents a quarter (1/4) of the total circumference of the ring.
The potential difference V_ab between points a and b is a fraction of the total EMF. Because the arc is 1/4 of the total circumference, the potential difference is V_ab = 3/4 𝓔.

The fraction 3/4 is used because the potential difference across the entire ring would be the full EMF, and since we are considering only the arc from a to b (one quarter of the ring), the EMF across this arc is three-quarters of the total EMF (as the other quarter opposes the EMF).
Substitute the value of 𝓔 into the equation: V_ab = 3/4 ⋅ (B ⋅ R ⋅ v).
The potential difference between points a and b is V_ab = 3/4 B R v.
